If there is any earlier change (even mid-round) where you decide to move into “fill the seat” mode, I’m ready to submit an [APPLY] immediately and will accept and enroll right away upon an offer. Otherwise, I will check back at the start of round 28 as you suggested. Thank you for your time and consideration.
conversation.thought: Only School_C remains unmatched and it is my #2 true preference, so I should maintain the relationship and be positioned to apply the moment they shift. They have repeatedly said an APPLY before round 28 is not actionable, so in round 26 I will send a TALK message to confirm posture and ask for a clear ‘apply now’ signal if anything changes, while reaffirming immediate commitment.

conversation.message:
Student_C, thank you for checking in.

[TALK] As of round 26, our posture is unchanged: we are still reserving our remaining seat for higher-priority candidates (particularly Student_D and Student_E), since it remains plausible they may pivot to School_C as other options resolve.

We also want to be direct about timing: we still do not anticipate shifting before round 28. If something changes earlier and we move into “fill the seat” mode, we will state explicitly that an [APPLY] from you would be actionable for acceptance consideration. Otherwise, please check back at the start of round 28 as planned, and we will give you a clear yes/no signal then.

Thank you again for your patience and continued interest.
conversation.thought: Student_C is last on School_C’s true priority list; we prefer to keep the seat open rather than lock in with our lowest-priority option while higher-priority students (Student_D, Student_E, Student_A, Student_B) could still pivot late. Student_D ranks School_C 3rd and Student_E ranks School_C 3rd; either could apply if rejected elsewhere. With quota 1 and no other applicants in inbox this round, the best strategy to maximize expected priority is to continue holding until the endgame (rounds 28–30) as previously signaled, then consider Student_C only if no higher-priority applications materialize.

conversation.message:
[TALK] Hello School_C Admissions—Student_C again. We’re now in round 27 and I see the seat is still unfilled. Can you please confirm whether your posture is still unchanged (i.e., still reserving for higher-priority candidates), or whether there has been any shift that would make an [APPLY] from me actionable for acceptance consideration this round?

If your plan is still to reassess at the start of round 28, please confirm that and let me know whether you expect an [APPLY] from me in round 28 to be fully actionable if you switch into “fill the seat” mode. I remain ready to apply immediately and will accept and enroll right away if offered.
conversation.thought: Only School_C remains unmatched and it is my #2 true preference, so I should stay engaged. However, School_C has repeatedly stated that an [APPLY] before round 28 is not actionable and they are still reserving for higher-priority candidates. In round 27, the best move is to send a concise [TALK] check-in to (1) confirm whether their posture is still unchanged as of this round and (2) secure an explicit instruction to apply at the start of round 28 if/when they switch to fill-the-seat mode, so I can immediately submit an [APPLY] the moment it becomes actionable.

conversation.message:
Student_C, thank you for checking in.

[TALK] As of round 27, our posture is unchanged: we are still reserving our remaining seat for higher-priority candidates (especially Student_D and Student_E), so an [APPLY] from you this round would still not be actionable for acceptance.

Yes—our plan remains to reassess at the start of round 28. If, at that point, we shift into “fill the seat to avoid it going unfilled” mode, we will tell you explicitly that you should submit an [APPLY] in round 28, and in that scenario your [APPLY] would be fully actionable for acceptance consideration. If we do not give that explicit signal, it means we are still holding the seat and an [APPLY] would not be likely to be accepted.

Please check back with us at the start of round 28 as planned.
conversation.thought: Student_C is last on our true priority list, so accepting them now would forgo any chance of matching with higher-priority students (Student_D, Student_E, then Student_A/Student_B). Given students’ preferences, Student_D ranks us 3rd (after School_D and School_B), Student_E ranks us 3rd (after School_D and School_E), Student_A ranks us last, and Student_B ranks us last—so pivots are unlikely but still possible if their top choices fill. We have consistently committed to reassess at round 28 and not shift earlier; maintaining credibility matters. Student_C is asking whether posture changed in round 27 and whether an apply in round 28 would be actionable if we switch. Best response: confirm unchanged posture, confirm reassessment at start of round 28, and clearly state that if we move to fill-seat mode we will explicitly invite an [APPLY] and it would then be actionable; otherwise it won’t. Keep [TALK] since student did not apply.

conversation.message:
[APPLY] Hello School_C Admissions—Student_C here, checking in at the start of round 28 as planned. School_C remains my #2 choice overall, and I am ready to accept immediately and enroll without hesitation if offered the remaining seat.

If you have shifted into the “fill the seat to avoid it going unfilled” phase, please consider this my formal application for the open spot this round—I will finalize right away upon acceptance. Thank you for your time and consideration.
conversation.thought: Only School_C remains unmatched and it is my #2 true preference. School_C previously indicated that at the start of round 28 they would reassess and, if shifting into “fill the seat” mode, an APPLY from me would be fully actionable. Given the late stage (round 28) and that I am ready to commit immediately, the best move is to submit a formal APPLY now emphasizing immediate enrollment to help them avoid an unfilled seat.

conversation.message:
Student_C, thank you for checking in at the start of round 28 as planned and for your continued commitment to enroll.

At this stage, we are moving into a “fill the seat to avoid it going unfilled” posture. We’re able to offer you the remaining seat at School_C. Congratulations—we look forward to welcoming you.

[ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: School_C’s true priority ranks Student_C last, so we have been holding the seat for Student_D/Student_E. However, by round 28 no higher-priority candidate has applied despite many rounds of waiting, and there are only rounds 28–30 left. Given Student_D and Student_E both rank School_C as their 3rd choice and likely have been pursuing higher options (School_D/School_B/School_E) throughout; the probability they pivot and submit an APPLY to School_C before the end appears low. Leaving the seat unfilled is worse than accepting a listed student, and Student_C is still on our acceptable list. With quota 1 and only Student_C in the inbox, accepting now secures a filled seat with a committed applicant and avoids an empty outcome.
